ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read and understand scientific papers, run experiments, basic lab upkeep and managerial tasks, input data, speak with experiment participants, participate in lab discussions, write and apply for grants, and code looking times.
It helped me to develop as a researcher!
Hands-on experience working in a lab and what goes into doing research
I learned a lot about what research looks like, this is a very good introduction to the research world.
Independent work and time management t

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: everything. It is an incredibly undergrad-focused lab and I could not be more happy having chose to work there. I learned so much this semester and particularly enjoyed being in the lab and running experiments. 

Weakness: almost feel like I'm not in the lab enough.
Building on what I had gained during my research-filled gap year, this course allowed me to further learn how to write a thorough research proposal and conduct multivariate fMRI analyses.
There could be more bonding activities.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. However, this course is what you make of it. The lab makes it so that you can achieve a lot of really great things but if you don't take advantage of it you're kind of just going to fill a space that someone else could have had that is really motivated to learn. I would say only apple to the lab if you're actually going to make good use of your time there.
Yes!! I definitely recommend doing directed research at some point during your Yale experience, especially if you are a cog sci major.
Yes, it's a great way to do research for your thesis!

If you are a cognitive science major and want some hands-on experience that can help fulfill the depth requirement this is a great option. Obviously your specific experience will vary based on the lab you work with but it was a great way to learn about the research process.
Yes I would if they have a strong interest in animal cognition and cognitive science.
